TOTAL RECOUNT
The company conducting an anonymously fundedÂ hand recount of 2.1 million ArizonaÂ ballots from last year's presidential election conducted an equally mysterious audit in one rural PennsylvaniaÂ countyÂ first,Â the Arizona Mirror reports.

RepublicanÂ Pennsylvania state Sens. Doug Mastriano and Judy Ward asked Fulton CountyÂ officials to allow the West Chester-based Wake Technology Services Inc. to conduct an audit of the county's 2020Â election, which local officials did.Â 

Mastriano, a prominent booster of meritless 2020 election fraud theories,Â did not respond to multiple messages from theÂ Mirror, an onlineÂ outletÂ launched with a progressive fund's backing. Ward said she passedÂ along the auditÂ request to Fulton County officials on Mastriano's behalf.Â 

The reporting provides new insight into some of theÂ players and motives behind Arizona's contentious, chaotic,Â and highly secretiveÂ recount effort â€” one the Washington Post says has inspired similar pushesÂ in communities nationwide.

But plenty of questions remain, including:
  • Who paid for the Fulton County audit?Â (AÂ county commissioner said he has no idea.)
  • Why audit a county former President Donald Trump won by a 6-to-1 margin?
  • And why isÂ Wake Technology Services Inc., a techÂ company focused on theÂ health-care sector, conducting election audits in the first place?

THE CONTEXT: A state-run pilot audit of Pennsylvania's 2020 election results confirmed in March that President Joe Biden was rightly declared the winner here but, as is typical of theÂ medium,Â didn'tÂ revealÂ how well the election was administered on a county-by-county or precinct-level basis, Spotlight PA and Votebeat found.

Election oversight hearings were also convened in Harrisburg, with RepublicansÂ calling themÂ a necessary endeavor post-2020 andÂ Democrats a cover for voter suppression.Â 

Now, afterÂ six months of calling for changes to Pennsylvaniaâ€™s Election Code, Republicans are finally set to unveil their proposalsÂ â€”Â stricter voter ID, earlierÂ registration deadlines, and mandatory signature verification on mail ballots all possible.

Meanwhile, State Sen. Ryan Aument (R., Lancaster) on Friday announced he'll beÂ introducingÂ legislation to suspend no-excuse mail ballots, whichÂ he and other Republicans supportedÂ in 2019.

VACCINE UPDATE: Fully vaccinated Americans who have beenÂ exposed toÂ COVID-19 but who are asymptomatic themselvesÂ can largely skip getting tested for the virus now, the CDC says. The CDC is alsoÂ probing a small number ofÂ reported cases of heart problems in teenagers and young adults who have received the shots, per the New York Times.Â For vaccine providers, use the federal government's online tool,Â call 1-800-232-0233, or textÂ your zip code to 438829 (GETVAX).

DAILY RUNDOWN

GIFT BAN:Â For many state lawmakers, 2020 was a banner year for staying home â€” and eschewing people bearing gifts, at least according to their limited disclosure forms. Pennsylvania is in theÂ minority of statesÂ with no limit on the size or number of gifts elected officials can accept. AÂ renewedÂ effort is pushingÂ to change that by banning legislator gifts altogether. History says it faces aÂ steep climb, per Spotlight PA.

RELIEF REQUEST: PennsylvaniaÂ Auditor General Timothy DeFoor wants the authority and the money to hire private accounting firms to keep tabs on the $13.5 billion in federal aid state and local governments will soon receive, via City & State. Pennsylvania is set to receive its largest share of federal relief dollars yet through the American Rescue Plan, andÂ DeFoor said it needs to be protected against waste and fraud.

CRISIS RESPONSE: Voters gave state lawmakers new power last Tuesday overÂ a governor's disaster declarations,Â an ongoingÂ pandemic order being front of mind for most. But the future of aÂ years-old and still-urgentÂ opioid epidemic-inspired declaration is also uncertain, with a GOP spokespersonÂ telling Capital-Star that Republicans in the majority will work with Gov. Tom Wolf before deciding what to do.

RECENT HISTORY: U.S. Rep. Scott Perry (R., Pa.) voted last week against a 9/11-style commission to study the Jan. 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol. Pressed by a C-SPANÂ caller, Perry downplayed the violence, saying there were "no arms that came in as far as I know, other than the people who were armed at the Capitol as security." WITF reports that's far from true, according to federal charging documents tied to the attack.

STEP DOWN:Â A powerful union representing 36,000 Pennsylvania educators is calling for the resignation of every Public School Employees Retirement System board member appointed before January 2021,Â according to PennLive.Â The Pennsylvania chapter of the American Federation of Teachers says scandals swirling around the $64 billion pension fund have jeopardized the financial security of its members.
IN OTHER NEWS
SANTORUM SPLIT: Rick Santorum, a former U.S. senator from Pennsylvana, is now a former CNNÂ political commentator, too, having been dropped by the network over ahistorical and revisionist comments about Native Americans and his subsequent attempt to explain theÂ remarks,Â HuffPost reports.

NEW HOME: When Texas Sen. Ted Cruz recently lamented and politicized the "jack-hammering" of a First Amendment monument at the former Newseum in D.C., fact-checkers and ratio-happy Twitterati were quick to note the monument wasn't actually destroyed but ratherÂ relocated to Philadelphia.

HUMAN TOUCH: Pitt bioengineers and a man who lost significant mobility in a car crash have createdÂ a robotic arm controlled by his brain. It used to only receive signals, but now it's sending sensory touch information back and greatly increasing the technology's effectiveness, WESA reports.Â 

CHALK DAD: Westmoreland County dad Erik Greenawalt'sÂ life-like, three-dimensional chalk drawings cover Dr. Seuss, "Schitt's Creek," Dwight Schrute, and more. Greenawalt is self-taught and told KDKA-TV about his favorite works and the downside of being a chalk artist in a rainy climate.

CASH MONEY: Someone in Pennsylvania won more than half a billion dollars over the weekend.Â It's unknown exactly where in Pennsylvania the winning $515 million lotto ticket was sold. I'll provide an update and my Venmo handle for the winner ASAP.
